author: Heather Simpson
title: Renwick site sought for 'movanners'
text:
Renwick site sought for 'movanners' HEATHER SIMPSON Last updated 17:46, October 15 2015 DEREK FLYNN/FAIRFAX NZ 
New Zealand Motor Caravan Association Marlborough committee chairman Sid Nally says they are looking for a site in Renwick for movanners. 
A Renwick community group is on the hunt for land as part of plans for a motor caravan park in the township. 
Renwick smart and connected want a 4000 square metres piece of land to provide a park up spot for motor caravanners or 'movanners'. 
The laid back lifestyle of recreational travel has attracted 1000 Marlborough members to the New Zealand Motor Caravan Association. 
The association has 30 parks dotted around New Zealand. 
Renwick smart and connected saw a gap in the market. 
Steering group member Ian Bird said Renwick was in a strategic position for the caravan site. 
It was close to Nelson and Blenheim and was a gateway to the West Coast. 
Motorhome tourism generated more than $650 million annually nationwide. 
"We want to promote Renwick as a destination to bring visitors here to enjoy our beautiful wine country, rather than stop over for just one night," Bird said. 
The land should be close to the township's supermarket and pubs, Bird said. 
Smart and connected would be the facilitator for the plans but any deal to buy or lease land would be struck between the landowner and the Motor Caravan Association. 
If a suitable site was found the association would carry the expense, Bird said. 
Ideally the land would have a water supply and a dump station to be used by members and the public. 
Bird said movanners were a different clientele to freedom campers. 
"They are not the kind of people to make a noise or have parties. They tend to be middle-aged people. They are good neighbours. 
"The association is very responsible. It is serious about protecting the environment. 
"I hope the community can get behind it. If we don't get a site it will be a lost opportunity. If someone has suitable land to lease or buy please let us know." 
The Marlborough committee of the New Zealand Motor Caravan Association would manage the site. 
Committee chairman Sid Nally said two areas had already been looked at. 
If land was found and the park got the go-ahead, it would cater for 100 self-contained caravans. 
They wanted a park where members could stay for three nights, charging $4 a night. 
The park would have to be fenced and gated and only members would have a key to keep out freedom campers, Nally said. 
The association had 1000 members in Marlborough and 60,000 nationwide. 
Movanning was continually rising, Nally said. 
"It's the Kiwi way to get out and visit out of the way places. 
"If we can get a small percentage of those people to come to Renwick it will be great for business. Imagine all those people going into Renwick to grab a coffee, buy some groceries or get a beer in the tavern." - The Marlborough Express
